speaker: Mrs May (Mcpherson) (11.32 Am)
theText: There is no doubt there has been a quiet revolutionmittee regarding the increased risk of injury for labour hire workers and independent contractors. Some evidence to the committee stated that workplace health and safety of labour hire workers is not as good as that of direct employees. Evidence to the inquiry also indicated there was confusion about responsibilities between labour hire agencies and host businesses. This uncertainty at times meant that either party may not acknowledge OH&S responsibilities. Occupational health and safety issues were of huge concern to me, and I believe that is reflected by recommendations 6, 7, 8 and 9. These four recommendations clearly spell out some guidelines for responsibilities in this area. It is important, in my view, that labour hire companies and host businesses have a clear set of national guidelines to protect the safety of independent contractors in the workplace. These four recommendations cover such areas as training for workers by labour hire agencies and host businesses, monitoring and enforcing compliance with occupational health and safety regulations, improving the collection of data on injury rates for independent contractors so comparisons can be made against direct employees and the development of initiatives to ensure greater understanding among independent contractors and host businesses of respective responsibilities in relation to occupational health and safety. This inquiry was difficult and challenging in the first instance because of the need for greater clarity and consistency in distinguishing between an employee and an independent contractor. There were conflicting views on what constituted a contractor, as distinct from an employee. I felt that it was important to clarify the difference. The committee noted in the report that different definitions of ‘employee’, ‘independent contractor’ and ‘employer’ in Commonwealth and state jurisdictions have been the subject of long standing concern. The report notes that differentiating between independent contractors and employees has required the common law to provide guidance. It was also noted that the courts need to use factors rather than a definition to determine employment status. The huge volume of evidence in this area provided substantial detail on many of these matters, and the evidence is summarised in the report. Careful consideration was given to all the evidence in determining what an independent contractor is, and government members recommended that the Australian government maintain the common law approach to determining employment status and distinguishing between employees and legitimate independent contractors. Overall, as a committee, each of us wanted to ensure that government did not in any way hinder the growth of independent contractors. It was well recognised that a balance between protections and freedoms for independent contractors had to be reached. As more and more Australians set up businesses that see them delivering services to a host of industries as independent contractors, we as legislators must be mindful of not dampening the entrepreneurial spirit. We must put safeguards in place, but those safeguards must not hinder the growth of the independent contractor in this country. We must recognise and embrace the cultural change that is happening in Australia’s labour market. This cultural change is in response to a changing global market, the competitiveness of business and the rise of franchising in this country, but more importantly it is a response to the individual who is choosing how he works and for whom he works. This individual is now taking on board responsibility for his working life. He wants the freedom of working for himself, with the choices that allow him to meet his demands and the demands of family responMAIN COMMITTEE sibilities, hours of work and income needs. This person wants to be independent; this person does not want to work for an employer. In other words, these people have chosen to work as independent contractors because it suits their lifestyle or income preferences. The Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations has indicated that in drafting the independent contractors act, which will be introduced into the parliament later this year, he will actively consider the committee’s report and its recommendations. The minister has further indicated that this government respects the rights of genuine independent contractors to manage their own affairs and to enter into their own agreements with their clients, if that is their preference. The growth of independent contractors certainly warrants the acknowledgement and support of government. Unfortunately for my opposition colleagues, there are now more independent contractors than there are trade union members in the Australian work force. This is a fact that should be acknowledged. It is a stark fact that shows just how much the Australian work force has changed and where it is moving to. As a government we need to protect the rights of independent contractors to work in the way they want, while ensuring the necessary safeguards are put in place so that they are not hindered in delivering the myriad services to industry that are so crucial to the continued economic growth of this country. To all my colleagues on the committee, and I note there are some opposition members of the committee here this morning, my thanks to each and every one of you for the spirited debate during the course of the inquiry. As the chairman of the committee noted in his tabling speech, even though there was dissent along party lines on some of the recommendations, overall there was unified support for the majority of the report, and there was certainly a huge commitment by all to ensure that a useful and informative report was finally tabled in the parliament. I commend the report to the House. Ms ANNETTE ELLIS (Canberra) (11.42 am)-I am pleased to have the opportunity today to make some brief comments in relation to the report entitled Making it work: inquiry into independent contracting and labour hire arrangements, which was tabled in the House very recently. In so doing I open my remarks by first of all putting on the record my thanks to, and my respect for, the committee secretariat attached to this inquiry. I thank each one of them most sincerely for the assistance and guidance they offered to all of us as committee members. I also want to thank all colleagues on the committee, both government and my own colleagues, for the spirit in which the inquiry was conducted. I want to endorse all the comments made by my colleague Brendan O’Connor, the Deputy Chair of the Employment, Workplace Relations and Workforce Participation Committee, who spoke earlier this morning. I do not wish to go over his comments again, but I want to endorse particularly his comments in relation to why we agreed on our side of the committee to put in our dissent to some aspects of the report. Members are extremely aware, and I am very aware, that most reports in this place are unanimous. It is does not happen every day that there are dissenting comments, and so they need to be observed as a serious contribution. We believe there are very good reasons for us to have those dissenting comments included. Having endorsed those comments by the deputy chair of the committee I want to talk about one particular aspect of the report this morning. It relates specifically to, in loose terms, the sorts of sham arrangements that can occur in the labour hire industry and to one case in particular. I wish to highlight this one case for a very clear reason, and the previous speaker, the member for McPherson, just mentioned it. While we are talking about this report there is also MAIN COMMITTEE a debate going on about changes to industrial relations legislation and the Welfare to Work arrangements. There is an interleaving going on between all of these subjects and a connection with this report. The case in point was brought to my attention by my own community in Canberra-a non-government organisation acting on behalf of a client of theirs. I will read some of the very brief submission that was made to the inquiry by this non-government organisation. In part, the submission states: I am bringing this case to your attention for your consideration as it demonstrates the vulnerability of people on the Disability Support Pension in the workplace, when there are not sufficient safeguards to protect their rights. There must be many similar cases across Australia where people on the DSP are subjected to these sorts of practices. Then there is a brief outline of the case. This is also referred to in the report at page 125, paragraph 5.142 and onwards. The case in point concerned a client on DSP for four years who has worked part time as a cleaner since October last year. This person was working 20 hours per week. She rang Centrelink each fortnight and informed them of her income and they adjusted her disability support pension accordingly. The client appears to have a mild intellectual disability. The client was worried about not paying any tax as the employer was not deducting any from her pay. The NGO rang the cleaning agency involved and was informed that the client was a subcontractor with the agency and that she had agreed to all the terms and had signed a contract. The client, however, said that she remembered signing some paperwork but she was not really sure what it meant, as she is not very good with forms. She was clearly very distressed and worried about possibly losing her job. The NGO subsequently sighted the contract that the client had signed but she had obviously no idea what it meant in relation to her employment. The client says she likes her cleaning job and wants to keep it; she does not understand the implications of being a subcontractor, or know what it even is. She receives a weekly pay packet and does not invoice the agency. They ring her and offer her work each week. She has regular customers that she cleans for. Superannuation, workers compensation insurance, holidays et cetera are all issues that obviously need clarification. The point here is that this person thought she was working-and she was-but she did not know that she was being employed as a subcontractor with all the implications that brings. It reached the point where she was asking Centrelink to take out the tax. She had to apply for an ABN. She did not even know how to begin to do the paperwork for an ABN, let alone understand the implications of what it meant. The client subsequently brought in the ABN application and, when the NGO officer asked her whether she understood the form at all, she became distressed and said it was all too much for her. At that stage in the proceedings the service involved was working with the client to investigate options for any other work and any issues with regard to the possible tax debt that this person now faces. I am not certain at this stage where that tax debt is up to. The reason for bringing the matter up is evident. My colleagues on the committee were also very interested in this case. It just shows that when we talk about subcontracting arrangements, employment possibilities and influencing people in a positive way to move from welfare to work, there are many considerations that we must have in mind. It is never quite as simple as many of us would wish it to be. This is not an isolated case. There will have been, will be and will continue to be many instances around the country where people are taken MAIN COMMITTEE advantage of in circumstances such as this. In my view, there has been an avoidance of obligations on the part of the employer-if we can determine that they are the employer under the arrangements to do with identity and clarification in labour hire circumstances. There has been a move by some people to remove themselves from their obligations in terms of their employer status. People like this woman can get very badly caught up in that. She ended up, as I have said, an unfortunate client of the Taxation Office, to whom she had a debt. Heaven knows what other circumstances would have flowed from that. I say to the government, in the most genuine and earnest way, that when we are talking about all these issues to do with people on DSP and maybe some who are not-maybe some who do not have literacy or numeracy skills or have other circumstances to assist them-there are very vulnerable folk out there who can fall foul through no fault of their own of all these things we are talking about. Nothing would make me happier than to see as many as possible of those people who find themselves in circumstances where they need disability support pension to exist financially have a more fruitful life out in the community participating along with the rest of us, but we cannot just sit back and assume that they all have the wherewithal to do that and we cannot just sit back and assume that all employers will do the right thing by them. The majority of them will, but there will be a hell of a lot of them who will not. I am really grateful to the committee and to the chair that we were able to put this example prominently in the report and talk about it at some length. IfI have any disappointment, it is in the fact that we have some dissent to recommendation 15 in the report. While our dissent is clearly outlined in our dissenting report-and it has everything to do with industrial relations-in paragraph 1.23 of our dissenting report, under ‘Opposition to Recommendation 15’, we say: In the event that the Commonwealth successfully implements a national industrial relations system the Australian Government should first clearly define an “employee” by adopting the definition as outlined earlier in this dissenting report. Further more the Australian government should legislate to prevent forms of disguised employment. This case, and others like it, come under this banner fairly well. I strongly suggest to the minister and to the government that when they make changes they seriously consider these sorts of implications. As I said a moment ago, this is only one instance. I am grateful to the agency for making the submission available to the committee. I have to say very honestly that I do not believe one member of the committee disagreed with the notion that we were in general terms putting forward about circumstances such as this. I know all members on the committee would agree with me-and they did at the time-that this is far from a satisfactory arrangement. My fear is just how many others like this are occurring. It is relevant to this report. I am concentrating my remarks purely on this because I think it is so important, and I hope that the remarks that are being made by members opposite on the adoption of the report by the government will allow the government to consider the comments we have made in our dissenting report and why they are there. This is one example that I would like to draw to the government’s attention. the report of the Standing Committee on Employment, Workplace Relations and Workforce Participation titled Making it work: inquiry into independent contracting and labour hire arMAIN COMMITTEE
title: Committees

speaker: Mr Henry (Hasluck) (11.53 Am)
theText: I am very pleased to have this opportunity to speak torangements. I would also like to put on record my appreciation of the opportunity I was given to participate in this inquiry and also thank the secretariat for the fantastic support they provided over the course of the inquiry. The inquiry brought to light not only a number of issues and a number of challenges in independent contracting and labour hire but also a growth of people wanting this level of independence and choice in their working life, which I support. The report highlights the conditions faced by Australia’s estimated million-plus independent contractors that find themselves under siege by state legislation and union intimidation in many cases and their being poorly served by any federal legal framework under which they can work. This is of particular concern when you consider that in Australia today a significant proportion of the work force is engaged in independent contracting. Indeed, it is a growing phenomenon. Independent contracting has become a lifestyle choice for what is, according to the figures provided by Independent Contractors of Australia, around 28 per cent of the country’s labour force. These million or more hard working men and women are engaged in running home based businesses, providing specialist advice in a range of fields such as marketing consultants, financial consultants, IT professionals, service providers and as subcontractors to the manufacturing, construction and building sectors. They represent a significant sector of our economy. We cannot ignore their needs and the challenges that face them. The report entitled Making it work that is before you contains a summary of the wide range of views on independent contracting and labour hire arrangements that were expressed to the Standing Committee on Employment, Workplace Relations and Workforce Participation during the eight days of hearings that were held across Australia and which were contained in more than 70 submissions that were received. During those hearings, we heard evidence that made it clear that people want to have the choice to be independent and benefit from the flexibility that life as an independent contractor will allow. They want to be, in effect, in charge of their own destiny in their working life. They do not want to be employees, they do not want to be tied to a single employer; they want choice, although many of them may work for a single organisation, business or entity for a period of two or three years-or more or less-depending on what they decide at the time. With respect to labour hire, where people work as independent contractors for labour hire companies and are placed in such work environments as aged care, health, health care, hospitality or tourism entities and organisations-or a range of similar service organisations-we see that, in cases where they have the option to switch to being a permanent employee, on almost all occasions they choose to remain as a contractor because of the flexibility it affords in their individual circumstances. That is not always the case, although I am informed that on all occasions these people are given the option of becoming employees if they are going into a long-term arrangement with a client of a labour hire company. Independent contractors in many ways epitomise the entrepreneurial spirit of Australia and contribute to Australia’s prosperity and the vibrancy of the communities in which they operate. In his speech last week to the Independent Contractors of Australia, the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations, the Hon. Kevin Andrews, described independent contracting as ‘one of the most important, yet least commented on, shifts in the history of its labour market’. I agree with this assessment, and I think there is evidence in the report to support that MAIN COMMITTEE sentiment as well. From evidence gleaned by the committee at the hearings, and through briefings from such organisations as Independent Contractors and others, it has become apparent that most trade unions are opposed to the rise of independent contractors and are actively engaged-with the help of some of the Labor controlled state governments that benefit from donations made by unions to the Labor Party coffers-in activities that are designed to force independent contractors back into traditional industrial relations systems. That is not a welcome development and it needs to be addressed. Fundamentally, the Labor Party and the unions seem unable to grasp the concept of independent contractors, because those contractors have little interest in joining the union movement. In this regard, I am strongly of the view that independent contracting represents a commercial relationship between the parties involved and under no circumstances should they be considered as requiring regulation under state industrial relations or workplace relations regimes. I am totally opposed to state deeming measures which seek to treat independent contractors as employees and which reduce the independence of those contractors through prescriptive legislation. There is a certain hypocrisy involved when these Labor controlled state governmentsand the unions that support them-talk about freedom of association when in fact they are actively seeking to reduce the choice and freedom of individuals to operate as independent contractors, putting them back into the industrial relations environment. In my home state of Western Australia the state government has been seeking to effectively deem independent contractors through its industrial relations legislation by expanding the definition of what constitutes an employee to include, as examples, outworkers, labour hire workers and contract cleaners. In Queensland, section 275 of the Queensland Industrial Relations Act 1999 gives the Queensland Industrial Relations Commission the power to declare persons who work under a contract for service to be an employee. Evidence from the ACCI suggested that removing deeming of individual contractors or employers from the Australian system of labour laws and precluding the operation of state deeming provisions should be supported. I support these propositions. The Making it work report tabled 16 recommendations that were supported by the majority of committee members; however, only nine of those were supported by all parties. A further seven minority report recommendations were tabled by the Labor Party members. These alternatives are certainly not supported by the majority of committee members. It is refreshing to see that at least on a number of recommendations there has been crossparty support; however, the differences identified are fundamental and occur in a number of what I believe to be crucial areas. There is certainly cross-party support for recommendations made in relation to statistical data collection, improvements in work safety, achieving consistency in terms of workers’ compensation systems and the development of educational resources. Sadly, but perhaps predictably, the recommendations made in the report which Labor members have declined to support are the very ones that are crucial to ensuring the flexibility of working arrangements enjoyed by independent contractors. Labor, it seems, because of their Tweedledum and Tweedledee relationship with the unions, want to continue to frustrate the use of independent contractors in order to drag them back into the grasp of rigid state controlled workplace relations systems, with many claims of sham arrangements. MAIN COMMITTEE As part of the report, the committee strongly recommended that the Australian government maintain the common law approach to determine employment status and to distinguish between employees and legitimate independent contractors. The common law approach is the common sense approach and has the overwhelming support of the independent contractors of Australia. The Independent Contractors of Australia describe this approach as the bedrock of Independent Contracting. This is not an opinion shared by Labor. The minority report suggests an alternative approach and trots out, in the words of the ICA: ... an incoherent shambles that would create massive commercial confusion and effectively dump known and stable commercial legal systems and relationships. The Labor alternative amounts to a tacit banning of independent contracting and labour hire. Remarkably, it also flies in the face of the acceptance by the International Labour Organisation of the legitimacy of independent contracting. The majority recommendations in the Making it work report are designed to ensure that independent contractors can be treated on a commercial basis as small businesses and thereby take advantage of a whole raft of commercial law protections and remedies offered to other enterprises. Unions that attack and deride the role of the independent contractor do so for selfserving purposes. Conservative estimates put the number of independent contractors at around 1.1 million and growing, while the ICA figures suggest that there may be as many as 1.9 million independent contractors. If that is the case, they now outnumber union membership, which has been on the decline for many years while, in contrast, the independent contractors’ star has been rising. The union movement, in concert with its Labor Party mates, would love to force union membership upon them. Indeed, Labor controlled state governments have introduced legislation to include specific provisions into their industrial relations laws to enable unions to treat independent contractors as though they were employees. Independent contractors add enormous value to the Australian economy and their growth is very much an unheralded success story. But that success has meant that independent contractors have become the target of what is predatory action by the unions and Labor controlled state governments that seek to legislate in the industrial relations system where no regulation is sought by either the contractors or their clients. It is my belief that a party’s freedom to contract must be upheld and that independent contractors need greater certainty in commercial relationships. The majority party recommendations of this report, when taken in concert with the proposed independent contractors act, will ensure that these important tenets are upheld and protected. They will, for example, also prevent unions from seeking orders from the Australian Industrial Relations Commission to impose unreasonable constraints-constraints that have no place in today’s economic realityon the freedom of Australia’s independent contractors to work in Australian workplaces. There is no doubt that labour hire and independent contracting arrangements should continue to develop and grow, providing both flexibility and opportunities for workers and business in the growing and increasingly diverse Australian economy. I commend the report to the House. Ms HALL (Shortland) (12.05 pm)-I rise to support the recommendations made in the dissenting report of the Standing Committee on Employment, Workplace Relations and WorkMAIN COMMITTEE force Participation report entitled Making it work: inquiry into independent contracting and labour hire arrangements. Before doing so, I would like to thank the chair for the very constructive role that he played. It was quite obvious from the start of the inquiry that there would never be agreement on a number of the recommendations. This was recognised by previous speakers, including the member for McPherson. I was disappointed by the contribution by the member for Hasluck because he was not cognisant of, did not give consideration to or did not acknowledge the fact that this was the type of inquiry in which, no matter what happens, you are going to have two different views expressed in the report. That probably goes to the heart of the differences between the two sides of parliament when looking at issues like this. It is important to acknowledge that the chair played a very constructive role and was very mindful of the fact that this was the situation. I would like to thank the deputy chair. He played a very important role in drafting the recommendations in the dissenting report. He worked closely with all the members that supported those recommendations. Finally, I would also like to thank the committee secretariat for the work that they did and the support that they gave the committee. I would like to refer to the final point that the deputy chair made in his recommendation: that he found it ‘disappointing that the secretariat was not sufficiently resourced to assist’ the members that wished to make a dissenting report. All up, I think that as a committee, given the very difficult circumstances, we worked very well together. Those members that did make the effort to attend most of the hearings and inquiries probably learnt a lot about this subject and were able to fully understand the issues from all perspectives. Even those members supporting the body of the report could understand the concerns of the people who did not agree with it and would never support the recommendations outlined in the report. BeforeI go to the body of the dissenting report, I would like to place on record a couple of concerns that I have. My first concern is that the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations released his discussion paper during the inquiry. He actually pre-empted a lot of the findings of the inquiry. I think he sought to influence to some extent the government members that were involved in that inquiry. It really worries me that the discussion paper was released on the day that the committee was conducting hearings in Sydney. We were most concerned by the fact that the minister had released his discussion paper and there was a feeling that, even if it did not influence the members of the committee, it could create the perception that it would. The second concern I would like to place on the record relates to the final stages of the inquiry when we had representatives from the department attend hearings here in parliament. I think we are served very well by those people who work in most departments. I have found on all the committee hearings I have been involved in that when staff employed by departments attend they try and answer the questions that are put to them by members of the committee. And members of the committee are also mindful that there are certain questions that the department cannot answer. I was absolutely horrified on the last occasion that the department came to meet with the committee, before we went to the final stages of our deliberations, when one staff member blatantly refused to answer any questions put to him. He hedged, he ducked, he weaved-and not only from questions put to him by opposition members of the committee but also from questions put to him by members of the government. I thought that that was a very sad state of affairs, and I found it very disappointing, because it put a lot of MAIN COMMITTEE pressure on the other staff member that was there. Really, the point of our meeting with departmental officials is to clarify any points that we may have, particularly at the vital stage just before we go into report deliberations. I feel that it is extremely important for me to put that on the record because that was the first time. I had encountered it on any committee that I have been involved in in this parliament or, for that matter, in the New South Wales parliament. I was quite disappointed. There are a number of dissenting recommendations. Firstly, we do agree with recommendations 1, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9, 10, 11 and 13. The recommendations that we disagree with really go to the core differences between the government and the opposition on this issue. The first recommendation that we oppose is recommendation 2, which goes to the definition of what determines employment and what determines independent contracting. The government supports a common law approach whereas we feel, as set out in the dissenting report, the government should provide a new definition of employee and that this definition should clarify the issues and remove the vagaries so as to create certainty for all the parties involved. I thought that that was an eminently sensible approach to take, but unfortunately that was not the majority decision of the committee. NextI refer to recommendation 3 and, once again, the opposition members did not support that recommendation. We felt that there was a need to define independent contractor. A number of our recommendations went to the fact that we really believed that it was important to have those definitions in place. Recommendation 4 refers back to that vital need for a definition of employee. It is proposed to place the onus on those who seek to be independent contractors to establish that they are genuinely running a business. We received a lot of evidence during hearings and through submissions to the committee which showed that that was of great concern to all parties involved in independent contracting or employees. Unfortunately, I feel that this report is not going to address those concerns. I think there will continue to be ambiguity in relation to employees and independent contractors. The common law approach means that people will be forced into situations that could be quite costly. I feel we have let all the parties down. One thing that became very apparent during the hearings was the impact that the increased casualisation of the work force was having on many workers in Australia. One of the sessions I found most interesting was in Sydney when we received evidence from labour hire companies. I was very surprised to find that it is not unusual for a person to be employed by a labour hire company and work with the same employer for a number of years-three, four or five years. The one that astounded me was the employee, employed by a labour hire company, who had been working for the one company for seven years. To my way of thinking, that cannot be justified. The labour hire company advised the committee that quite often companies seek to employ people through labour hire because it is better for their bottom line and for their reporting requirements. People employed by labour hire companies do not enjoy the same conditions as other employees. That extends to being able to secure loans and mortgages and this pervades all areas of their life. This area needs to be addressed. Employers should not be able to abrogate their responsibility to their workers simply from the point of view of meeting the requirements of their bottom line. Another area of great concern in relation to labour hire was occupational health and safety. There was considerable confusion in relation to who bore the responsibility for an injured MAIN COMMITTEE worker-whether it was the host company, the labour hire agency or a joint responsibility. I believe this issue needs to be addressed. I have come across numerous examples within my own electorate of where this confusion has been evident, where host employers have sought to abrogate their responsibility to injured workers. Probably one of the worse cases I have heard of is a worker who had a steel rod rammed through their leg. The employer arranged for that person to be driven to the hospital because they did not want to involve the WorkCover Authority. They had a very questionable safety record and, by taking the worker to the hospital in private transport, sought to abrogate their responsibility. We really need to have proper legislation in place, not to have a voluntary code of conduct, but mandatory registration of labour hire companies. Labour hire companies recognise that there is a need for registration but we need to make sure that any change fits in with recommendation 23. That will make for a better, safe working environment for all concerned. The other issue relates to the TWU-probably one of the best presentations I have seen to any committee in this parliament. Drivers presented to the committee their concerns about proposed changes that will prevent them from being members of the TWU. (Time expired) dissenting members of the Standing Committee on Employment, Workplace Relations and Workforce Participation. While the majority of the recommendations of the committee were agreed upon unanimously, I trust that the government will take notice of the seven additional recommendations contained in the dissenting report presented by Labor members of the committee. Independent contractors and labour hire arrangements are a growing feature of the Australian workplace, and the evidence suggests that there is going to be some growth for some time to come. It is not about to stop-at least according to the evidence presented to the committee. It provides opportunities for employers to shift workers from being employees to being contractors while in effect remaining, to all intents and purposes, an employee. Probably the most disappointing thing about the report is that this failed to be taken up in any serious way. While it was acknowledged as an issue by the dissenting Labor members, the government members failed to pick up probably the single most important thing facing people who have been shifted from being employees to being contractors. The government members have missed a fantastic opportunity to address the concerns of these workers, who are becoming a larger and larger part of the Australian work force. I am a little torn about why this might be the case. On the one hand, it might be that people simply do not understand the concerns of these workers. On the other hand, it is perhaps because government members are actually supportive of the inherent unfairness of the arrangements, given their stance on other industrial issues. But it is most likely to be simply that government members do not care. The government simply does not care about many workers being forced into positions where they have to accept a contracting arrangement for the convenience of their employers. In most circumstances the employees who have quickly become so-called independent contractors are not facing anything different in terms of their work or their relationship with their employer, but they are certainly facing additional uncertainty-additional uncertainty borne out of not being on the books in the same way: as opposed to being on wages, they are there simply as independent contractors. speaker: Mr Hayes (Werriwa) (12.20 Pm)
theText: I would like to support the recommendations of theOf course, it does not stop there. The former employee, now a contractor, also faces considerable on-costs that once were borne by the employer. The contractor is expected to now make provision for their own superannuation, their own compensation premiums and any other insurance that may be required by the employer or by state or federal statute. While members opposite may say this is a fair thing, I have to say that from my perspective, and from that of the people in my electorate, it is completely unfair. The employer is getting all the benefits in the same way that they did before, but they are now able to avoid the additional on-costs associated with the direct hire of employees. The situation, quite frankly, is probably best described as all care with very little responsibility. In my opinion, this is a key thing that government members missed during this inquiry. Government members had the opportunity to recommend to the minister that, after weighing up all the evidence that was presented to them, there was a case for change. There was the opportunity to adjust what I consider to be these unfair arrangements. There was an opportunity to correct the record in that respect. They had the opportunity to support Labor’s bid to have an unfair situation corrected by recommending changes to the definition of an employee, moving away from a common-law definition and imposing an adjustment to the Workplace Relations Act. Instead, the government members stood firm with the decision to continue the situation in which an employer can get away with removing entitlements, exposing workers to unnecessary and unfair levels of risk, simply by redefining their classification. With the stroke of a pen, everything is removed and nothing is replaced when it comes to many cases of so called independent contractors. As the member for Gorton noted in his earlier speech on the report, there are myriad sham arrangements that have been entered into and taken advantage of by making employees contractors. These sham arrangements create a situation of disguising employment and they are simply unfair to workers who are forced to accept them, forced to take all of the risk and most of the cost-sometimes for very little or no additional return, I might add. These situations are simply wrong and should be stopped. It is not nearly good enough that they be allowed to continue and that people be allowed to take advantage of them, or at least of the results. The government had the chance to change this, or at least put on the record that it is wrong, by supporting a relatively simple amendment to the definition of ‘employee’. This could have been easily achieved through an amendment to the definition of employee contained in the Workplace Relations Act, as outlined in recommendation 2 of the dissenting report. The evidence to the committee was clear. When labour hire and independent contracting arrangements are entered into, the lines become extremely blurred. The lines are blurred not only for the purpose of assigning responsibility but also for the purposes of legal obligations that are created by these arrangements. The blurred lines and changed obligations mean that, at times, workers in these arrangements are far worse off than they ever were when they were direct hire employees. Their protections have been removed, their entitlements have been removed and they have additional on-costs foisted upon them. In most circumstances, when added up, this is all to their detriment. I note that the evidence to the committee showed that there are also concerns about permanency of arrangements, unreasonableness of working hours and the general treatment of the so-called independent contractor being worse than would have been the case had they remained as direct employees. These are serious issues and they reflect a legitimate concern for MAIN COMMITTEE those who are being taken advantage of under often unfair arrangements that they had no option other than to accept. I wonder if this is some sort of sign for the future of all other working Australians. The matters that this report deals with have a direct impact on many of my constituents. I know many of those in Werriwa are certainly concerned about the matters that came before this committee. RecentlyI had the opportunity to hear from and speak with a number of people who are deeply concerned about the government’s approach to independent contractors. These people were not just fearful for their own livelihoods but concerned about the future of their families. During the last sitting fortnight of this parliament, a delegation of independent contractors in the transport industry travelled to Canberra to defend their rights. This group rallied at the front of Parliament House in an effort to bring their plight and their fight to the members of this place. I attended that rally to show my support. Sadly, I have to say, I did not see many members from the opposite side there and that is probably why they are not so willing to participate in this debate. The transport workers also conducted a forum to which all members and senators were invited. The forum gave all of us here the opportunity to hear directly about their concerns. It also gave us the opportunity to hear from a number of experts, including academics in the field and wives and families of these contracted transport workers. While generally productive, the forum was interrupted by the member for O’Connor, who, it would seem, could not help himself when presented with an opportunity to put himself in front of a TV camera. Main Committee adjourned at 12.31 pm MAIN COMMITTEE Dapsone (Question No. 1322) Mr Edwards asked the Minister for Veterans’ Affairs, in writing, on 12 May 2005: (1) When and how extensively has Dapsone been used within the Australian Defence Force. (2) What side effects does Dapsone have. (3) Have tests ever been conducted in Australia to measure the side effects of Dapsone and have the results of these tests been made public; if so, where. (4) Have tests been conducted and results not been made public; if so, why. (5) Has Dapsone been linked to cancer. (6) Do US. Veterans’ studies show a link between Dapsone and brain tumours. Mrs De-Anne Kelly-The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows: The following answers are provided based on information available to the Department of Veterans’ Affairs. (1) The use of Dapsone as an anti-malarial was restricted to Vietnam. In Vietnam, Dapsone was first used in September 1967 when it became a drug used to treat active malaria. From November 1968 it was used as a malaria prevention drug. This continued until February 1970. During this time it is estimated that 23,400 persons took the drug. (2) Dapsone has a wide range of side effects. These include nausea, vomiting, headache and insomnia. Severe side effects include agranulocytosis, a condition in which the white blood cells die. (3) and (4) No tests have been made on Dapsone by DVA. The Department of Veterans’ Affairs commissioned several studies on the possible health effects of Dapsone. The largest of these was a cancer incidence study, which was released by the then Minister for Veterans’ Affairs in 1992. All studies were based on record searches, not testing of individuals. Two smaller record searches were also made, one of which was concerned with the side effects of Dapsone. They have been available to the public via the library of the Department of Veterans’ Affairs since 1994. Two case reports were published in the Medical Journal of Australia in 1970 and 1971. (5) No. There were suggestions of a carcinogenic effect in some reports several decades ago, but these have not been supported by more recent material. Dapsone is today not regarded as carcinogenic. (6) The Department of Veterans’ Affairs is not aware of any US studies that show a link between brain tumours and Dapsone. Medibank Private (Question No. 1926) Mr Georganas asked the Minister representing the Minister for Finance and Administration, in writing, on 9 August 2005: (1) Can he confirm whether a scoping study is under way or has been undertaken on the possible sale of Medibank Private. (2) Is the Government considering the sale of Medibank Private; if so, can he explain what benefits its sale would generate for its members. (3) What capital does the Commonwealth have invested in Medibank Private. (4) What proportion of the current assets of Medibank Private are derived from the contributions of its members. swer to the honourable member’s question: (1) The Australian Government undertook a scoping study into the future ownership options for Medibank Private Limited (Medibank Private) in the 2002-03 financial year. On 16 August 2005 the Minister for Finance and Administration, Senator the Honourable Nick Minchin, announced the Australian Government had decided to review its ownership of Medibank Private and will update the 2003 scoping study. The scoping study update is expected to be completed by the end of this year. (2) The Government is reviewing its ownership of Medibank Private through an update of the 2003 scoping study. The update will include a consideration of the effects of a potential sale on Medibank Private’s customers. (3) The Commonwealth has $85,000,100 in paid up capital in Medibank Private as at 30 June 2005. (4) There is no direct correlation between Current Assets and Member Contributions. Member Contributions are treated as revenue in the year they are received with any surplus derived from the financial year being recorded as Retained Earnings in the Balance Sheet. Total Current Assets for 2003-04 were $1.0 billion and Total Member Contributions for 2003-04 were $2.4 billion. Organ Donation (Question No. 1977) Mr Price asked the Minister for Health and Ageing, in writing, on 9 August 2005: In respect of his letter received in my office on 1 June 2005 concerning organ donation and the ability to register consent in the local Medicare office in my electorate, can he say which Medicare office in my electorate he had in mind. The letter received by the member for Chifley was sent to all Australian households inviting people to register as potential organ donors on the Australian Organ Donor Register. The letter and brochure enclosed with it referred to several options for people to submit their registration or to gain more information on organ donation, including by: Completing the registration form and sending it to: Reply Paid 711, Hobart, Tas, 7001; Registering online at www.hic.gov.au; Telephone: 1800 777 203; or Visiting their local Medicare office. The nearest Medicare office for residents in the Chifley electorate is the Blacktown Medicare office in the West Point Shopping Centre, Patrick Street, Blacktown.
